dataset.title: Biomass and numbers of microplankton (20-200um) in Arctic LTER lakes in 1992, including ciliated protozoans, rotifers and nauplii, Arctic LTER, summer 1992.

address.deliveryPoint: The University of North Carolina- Greensboro

abstract.para: Biomass and numbers of microplankton (20-200um) in Arctic LTER lakes in 1992, including ciliated protozoans, rotifers and nauplii.

intellectualRights.para: Acceptance and utilization of LTER data requires that:

listitem.para: The Principal Investigator be sent a notice stating reasons for acquiring any data and a description of the publication intentions.
The Principal Investigator of the data set be sent a copy of the report or manuscript prior to submission and be adequately cited in any resultant publications

A copy of any resultant publications should be sent to:
Principal Investigator Ecosystems Center Marine Biological Laboratory Woods Hole, MA 02543

description.para: Log of changes: For Archival Use: DATE RECEIVED: April 9, 1997 DATA FILE ENTERED BY: Neil Bettez DATA FILE VALIDATION: NAME: Neil Bettez DATE: April 9, 1997
Version 3: Updated metadata sheet to newer version (with sites sheet). CH April 2013.

para.literalLayout:
Samples were taken with a Van Dorn bottle, emptied into a pitcher, and 2 to 2.5 l was gently reverse-flow concentrated through a 20 um Nitex net. A final volume of 60 ml was preserved with glutaraldehyde to a final concentration of 1%. All samples were stored refrigerated until direct counting according to the method of Baldock (1989). Briefly, 5 - 15 ml was stained with Rose Bengal, drawn onto an 8.0 um pore cellulose acetate filter, mounted in 47% sucrose solution and the entire filter surface examined at 100x to 400x magnification. Individual protozoans and rotifers were identified to finest practical taxonomic level; nauplii were simply enumerated. Notes: This file is currently incomplete: data for other lakes is yet to be added.
Reference Citations: Baldock, B.M. 1986. A method for enumerating protozoa in a variety of freshwater habitats. Microb. Ecol. 12:187-191. Makarewicz, J.C. and G.E. Likens. 1979. Structure and function of the zooplankton community of Mirror Lake, N.H. Ecol. Monogr. 49:109-127. Pauli, H.-R. 1989. A new method to estimate individual dry weights of rotifers. Hydrobiol. 186/187:355-361. Putt, M. and D.K. Stoecker. 1989. An experimentally determined carbon:volume ratio for marine "oligotrichous" ciliates from estuarine and coastal waters. Limnol. Oceanogr. 34:1097-1104. Ruttner-Kolisko, A. 1974. Plankton rotifers. Biology and taxonomy. Die Binnengewasser, Suppl. Vol XXVI, part 1. Ruttner-Kolisko, A. 1977. Suggestions for biomass calculation of plankton rotifers. Arch. Hydrobiol. 8:71-76.
Sampling Description.
Sampling locations are designated by the lake sitecode numbers. All samples were taken at the "main" station - that normally used for synoptic sampling of nutrients, zooplankton etc. For lakes where samples are not routinely taken, samples were taken from the deepest known location in the lake.
All Biomass values are calculated based on measured biovolumes in preserved samples and literature conversion values from biovolume to carbon. For protozoans, individuals are placed into size categories, and a mean biovolume is then estimated by appropriate geometric formulas for volumes of a cone or sphere. Protozoan biovolume is converted to protozoan biomass using a conversion factor of 0.14 pg C æm-3 (Putt and Stoecker 1989). For rotifers, mean biomass values for individuals of each species were derived from direct measurements of dimensions and appropriate conversion factors to biomass derived from Ruttner-Kolisko (1977), Makarewicz and Likens (1979), and Pauli (1989).

project.title: Arctic Long-Term Ecological Research (ARC LTER) Program

para.literalLayout:
The goal of Arctic LTER project is to predict the future ecological characteristics of the site based upon our knowledge of the controls of ecosystem structure and function as exerted by physical setting and geologic factors, climatic factors, biotic factors, and the changes in fluxes of water and materials from land to water. To achieve this goal the Arctic LTER uses several approaches:
Long-term monitoring and surveys of natural variation of ecosystem characteristics in space and time. Includes: climate, plant communities and productivity, thaw depth, stream flow, chemistry of streams and lakes, temperatures of streams and lakes, lake chlorophyll lake productivity, zooplankton abundance.
Experimental manipulation of ecosystems for years and decades. Includes: tundra warming, shading, and fertilizing, grazer exclusions, fertilization of lakes and streams, addition and subtraction of predators.
Synthesis of results and predictive modeling at ecosystem and watershed scales. Includes: stream N cycling, lake physics, bioenergetics of fish populations, water movement and transfer of DOC and nutrients from land to water, soil respiration, cycling and storage of C in tundra under different scenarios of future climates.

funding.para: This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Grants #DEB-981022, 9211775, 8702328; #OPP-9911278, 9911681, 9732281, 9615411, 9615563, 9615942, 9615949, 9400722, 9415411, 9318529; #BSR 9019055, 8806635, 8507493. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: The Arctic LTER research site (68°N and 149°W) is in the foothills region of the North Slope of Alaska and includes the entire Toolik Lake watershed and the adjacent watershed of the upper Kuparuk River, down to the confluence of these two watersheds. This area is typical of the northern foothills of the Brooks Range, with continuous permafrost, no trees, a complete snow cover for 7 to 9 months, winter ice cover on lakes, streams, and ocean, and cessation of river flow during the winter. Tussock tundra vegetation of sedges and grasses mixed with dwarf birch and low willows form the dominant vegetation type with areas of drier heath tundra on ridge tops and other well-drained sites as well as areas of river-bottom willow communities.
